intro.description: The next step on our path to enlightenment is to ask ASSET to randomly generate a number of scenarios. To do this, we're going to add scenario generation elements to the control file.

item.title: View the scenario
item.description: Once again we'll start off by opening the scenario file (.asset) to see what we're going to change in each scenario.

item.title: Decide what to change
item.description: The analysis objective we're going to consider in our multiple scenario generation is to see how the Frigate's search speed affects how many targets are spotted. That's quite simple then, it's the Value attribute of the Speed element within the Wander behaviour titled Count fishing vessels.

item.title: Create duplicate controller file
item.description: We're going to base our multi-scenario simulation on the multi-participant simulation, so make a copy of trial_multi_part.xml titled trial_multi_scen.xml.

item.title: Add scenario generation code
item.description: Right, open our new scenario control file. Start off by specifying a new output folder, specify the OutputDirectory attribute as MultiScenarios. Add a MultiScenarioGenerator element to the ScenarioGenerator element. Set the Number to 100. Yes, we're going to create a hundred permutations of our scenario. Also, set the NameTemplate to ForceProt_ to keep our new scenarios easy to recognise

item.title: Specify the speed variance
item.description:
Next, add a Variance element to the VarianceList element of the MultiScenarioGenerator. Name this new Variance element SearchSpeed and specify the id as //Wander[@Name='Count fishing vessels']/Speed. Yes, that's a tricky string - so you're best off copying it diretly from this text.
By default the Variance element contains a single LocationArea element. We don't want this, so right-click on it and select Replace with an Attribute element. With our Fishing vessel wander speed we requested a range of values. In this case we're going to specify which ones to use. So, we need to replace the Range element with a Choice element (right-click, Replace With). Now give the Choice element 3 Value children, that have values of 4, 8, and 12. Also set the Name attribute to Value, since it's the Value attribute that we want to put our data values into.

item.title: Add a batch-run observer
item.description: Lastly for this scenario controller we're going to add a new observer - one that collates statistics across a series of model runs. Frequently these batch-run observers are normal observers with optional batch-run functionality. So, add a ProportionDetectedObserver to the ObserverList. Name it as Proportion of greens that got detected. Set the Target type to GREEN and the Watch type to BLUE. Then add a BatchCollator element to the ProportionDetectedObserver. Within the batch-collator, specify that OnlyBatchReporting is true, the CollationMethod is AVERAGE and PerCase is true. Read more on these settings via the adjacent help link.

item.title: Load the new scenario control file
item.description: Now drag the trial_multi_scen.xml file in to the Scenario controller view. You'll see the name of the control file update. Next, click on Generate to generate the 100 scenarios. Yes, it may take a couple of seconds.

item.title: Re-run the scenario
item.description: Right, now you can click on the Run button, and ASSET will work its way through the scenarios.

item.title: Inspect a results output
item.description: All of the outputs from the runs will be put in the MultiScenarios folder. In there you'll see lots of png and rep files. Feel free to open a couple to see the variety of outputs produced once we're varying multiple attributes.

item.title: Inspect a batch results output
item.description: The greater value of the multi-scenario runs, however is the batch run collation. So go into the MultiScenarios folder, and double-clicl Proportion of greens that got detected.csv file. ASSET will most likely open Excel, but you could have right-clicked on the item and selected open with text editor. In the Excel spreadsheet you'll see a table showing one row per speed choice we supplied, how many random scenarios used that speed setting, and the average proportion of fishing vessels that were detected using that search speed (typically, the faster you search the more targets you'll find - at least using our very simple cookie-cutter sensor).

item.title: Tutorial complete
item.description:
Ready are you? What know you of ready? For eight hundred years have I trained Jedi. My own counsel will I keep on who is to be trained.
There again, you've managed to complete the tutorial, so you must be fairly competent. You've been introduced to a slice across ASSET modelling, learn more either from the online ASSET Model Reference or from the ASSET Modelling Guide within the Asset Documentation Set. Both are available if you select Help Contents from the Help menu
